content:
• Thursday, March 24, 2016
  • TMUS

    FBR launches T-Mobile at Neutral amid capacity growth challenge

    • T-Mobile (TMUS -0.2%) faces limited organic growth in the future as it runs into capacity challenges, FBR notes in launching coverage of the stock at Market Perform.
    • Analysts David Dixon and Mike He set a price target of $40, implying just 8.1% upside from today's close of $37. TMUS is up 11.7% over the past 12 months, but is down 5.4% so far for 2016.
    • T-Mobile's network is set for near-term needs, and it should be an active player in the 600 MHz broadcast spectrum auction, but "expect BingeOn elasticity and the addition of low-band coverage spectrum to create a 4x multiplier increase for capacity demand."
    • Meanwhile, dramatically improving Sprint (S +3.8%) could gain momentum with low-cost capacity additions, they say: "We believe a resurgent Sprint could potentially overtake T-Mobile. If our view proves to be correct, we believe a stronger Sprint could make a successful attempt to acquire a potentially weakened T-Mobile under a new FCC administration."
     
     
     
     
    | 6:07 PM | 10 Comments

  • Weekly ETF Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: GAZ +4%. UUP +1.17%. XLV +0.85%. XLU +0.62%. IYH +0.53%.
    • Losers: TAN -8.44%. OIL -6.36%. GDX -5.58%. FCG -5.4%. GDXJ -5.03%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 5:51 PM | 2 Comments
  • HOLX

    HOLX, CNC, FR, BANC gain on S&P index changes; ESV slips

    • Abiomed (NASDAQ:ABMD) will take Hologic's spot in the S&P MidCap 400, and Ensco will take Centene's spot. First Industrial Realty Trust (NYSE:FR) will replace Health Net (just acquired by Centene) in the 400.
    • ServisFirst Bancshares (NASDAQ:SFBS) will replace National Penn Bancshares (about to be acquired by BB&T) in the S&P SmallCap 600 after the April 1 close. Banc of California (NYSE:BANC) will take Abiomed's spot in the 600.
    • HOLX +2% after hours. CNC +1.6%. FR +3.5%. BANC +3.5%. ESV -0.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:43 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: FR +3.5%. DRD +2.9%. TNK +2.8%. CONN +2.3%. HOLX +2.0%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: GME -5.5%. MT -5.3%. WMC -4.8%. FDC -4.5%. GBX -4.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 8 Comments
  • GME

    GameStop falls after mixed results, soft guidance

    • In addition to missing FQ4 sales estimates (while beating on EPS), GameStop (NYSE:GME) is guiding for FQ1 revenue to be down 4%-7% Y/Y, below a consensus for 1.3% growth. Net income is expected to drop to $60.5M-$66M from the year-ago period's $73.8M ($0.68/share). That suggests EPS will be below a $0.71 consensus. Same-store sales are expected to be down 7%-9% Y/Y.
    • FY16 (ends Jan. '17) guidance is for 0%-3% sales growth (compares with a 2.8% consensus) and net income of $407M-$423M (compares with FY15's $415.6M). Consensus has been for EPS to rise to $4.09 from FY15's $3.90. Same-store sales are expected to be flat to down 3%. The FY16 capex budget is at $160M-$170M.
    • Top-line performance: Same-store sales rose 3.1% Y/Y in FQ4 (3% in the U.S., 3.3% elsewhere), after having dropped 1.1% in FQ3. New video game hardware, video game accessory, digital, mobile/consumer electronics and "other" (e.g. collectibles) revenue rose. New video game software sales fell, and pre-owned sales were flat.
    • Financials: Lifting FQ4 EPS: Gross margin rose to 150 bps Y/Y to 29.6%. Also helping: $50M was spent to buy back 1.6M shares, leading total FY15 repurchases to amount to $202M (5.22M shares). Hurting EPS: SG&A spend was 17.4% of revenue, up from 15.8% a year ago.

      GameStop ended FQ4 with $450M in cash, $350M in debt, 1,036 "Technology Brand" stores, and 35 collectibles stores. Merchandise inventories stood at $1.16B, up slightly Y/Y.
    • Shares are down 5.6% after hours to $28.57.
    • GameStop's FQ4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:30 PM | 8 Comments
  • EE

    El Paso Electric upgraded, PNM Resources downgraded at Jefferies

    • El Paso Electric (EE +1.7%) is upgraded to Hold from Underperform with a $44 price target while PNM Resources (PNM +0.2%) is downgraded to Hold from Buy with a $34 target at Jefferies.
    • The firm raises EE, seeing the stock as fairly valued trading at a 5% discount to the group average P/E multiple given the two pending rate cases in Texas and New Mexico; while the New Mexico case will be delayed another month, a final settlement in Texas should be filed in the next week or two.
    • Jefferies cites New Mexico regulatory concerns in downgrading PNM, as the decision earlier this month to delay the in-service date of new rates adds a risk to 2016 earnings; PNM plans to file a second rate proceeding later this year that could extend the regulatory overhang another 12 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:25 PM
  • RRC

    Range Resources cut to Underweight at Barclays

    • Range Resources (RRC -1.5%) is downgraded to Underweight from Equal Weight with a $24 price target, cut from $27, at Barclays, which says the company has a deep inventory of attractive drilling locations but also faces cost structure challenges and a levered balance sheet.
    • Barclays believes RRC may be pressured as growth slows to a forecast 2% this year and 8% next year after 20%-25%/year growth over the past three years, adding that shares now enjoy a 40%-45% premium multiple but could fall nearly 50% to $17 if the premium multiple disappears.
    • RRC is well hedged for 2016, but Barclays estimates 2016 cash flow would be negative $100M at strip prices if $400M-plus in potential hedge gains were excluded; the firm says investors should be cautious when estimates include significant hedge gains.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:18 PM | 1 Comment
  • HPJ

    Highpower plunges after Q4 report; battery sales rise, gross margin slumps

    • Highpower (HPJ -16.2%) has tumbled below $2 after reporting its Q4 net income fell to just $167K from $2M in the year-ago period, in spite of a 7.2% Y/Y increase in revenue to $37.9M.
    • CEO George Pan notes ASPs for both Ni-MH and lithium ion batteries fell in 2015. The ASP pressure was one reason gross margin dropped 260 bps Y/Y in Q4 to 17.5%, and 140 bps over the whole of 2015 to 19.1%.
    • Lithium battery sales are benefiting from rising sales to the electric bus and "high-end consumer electronic device" markets. Excluding forex gains/losses, operating expenses rose to $6.8M in Q4 from $6.3M a year ago. Highpower ended 2015 with $5.8M in cash, $11.7M in restricted cash, and over $46M in debt.
    • Highpower's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 2:57 PM
  • MT

    ArcelorMittal to sell three of its U.S. steel operations

    • ArcelorMittal (MT +2.7%) agrees to sell three of its U.S. steelmaking and finishing operations to Black Diamond Capital Management for an undisclosed sum.
    • The deal includes the sale of MT's LaPlace, La., steel facility; a rolling mill in Harriman, Tenn., which produces long steel products such as billets, angles, flats, channels and beams; and the Vinton, Tex., facility, which produces rebar and grinding media, also long steel products.
    • MT has been making sales and recently raised $3B from a rights issue to strengthen its balance sheet and pay down debt.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:54 PM | 3 Comments
  • MEOH

    Methanex cut to Hold from Buy at TD Securities

    • Methanex (MEOH -2.4%) is downgraded to Hold from Buy with a $34 price target at TD Securities, which believes the company’s recent share price appreciation has outpaced the improvement in the outlook for methanol prices.
    • TD says that while its methanol forecast assumes an average realized price of $300/metric ton in 2017 and $325 in 2018 and beyond, the results would require a meaningful recovery relative to its estimate of $237/ton in Q1 2016 and $259 in full-year 2016.
    • Combined with the stock's 40% rebound off its recent low, the firm sees near-term risk as it expects the Q1 consensus EBITDA estimate will come down.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:45 PM
  • OUTR

    Outerwall reportedly prepping "Redbox Digital" streaming service; shares gain

    • Citing multiple sources and screenshot/logo leaks, Variety reports Outerwall (OUTR +5.3%) plans to launch a streaming service called Redbox Digital. One source states a closed beta test may be available soon.
    • Whereas the shuttered Redbox Instant streaming JV with Verizon aimed to fully challenge Netflix (which had major edges in content selection, hardware support, and consumer awareness), Redbox Digital is said to be a video-on-demand store similar to iTunes or Google Play, through which consumers will be able to rent or buy movies and TV shows. The service will reportedly integrate with Redbox's loyalty program and mobile apps.
    • The report comes ten days after Outerwall said it will explore strategic alternatives, and less than two months after activist Engaged Capital disclosed a position. With both subscription and on-demand streaming services taking a toll, Outerwall's Redbox revenue fell 17% Y/Y in Q4 to $407M, with movie rentals declining 24% to 135.8M.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:17 PM | 4 Comments
  • WATT

    Energous reacts to Seeking Alpha column, discusses ASIC progress

    • Two days after a column from Seeking Alpha contributor Richard X. Roe highlighted a disclosure in Energous' (WATT +3.8%) 2015 10-K indicating the company hasn't yet been able to charge multiple devices from one transmitter "at a commercially acceptable level," Energous CEO Steve Rizzone has provided a response (.pdf).
    • Rizzone, referencing 2015 tests on Energous WattUp transmitters from testing firm UL: "There can be no question as to whether or not the WattUp technology has the capability of sending significant power, at a distance to multiple devices ... The WattUp system used in conjunction with the UL tests was our first generation technology which did not have the size characteristics, efficiency and cost performance necessary to support a commercial product that would have mass acceptance by consumers. As a result, while fully operational, the technology used in the tests was not deemed commercially viable, so the clause was included."
    • He adds the clause "will likely be modified in future filings as we believe we have successfully integrated and improved the WattUp technology to the point where the ASIC silicon we currently have in qualification for production meets or exceeds our objectives for size, efficiency and cost for commercial viability on a mass scale"
    • Rizzone also claims a video screenshot in Roe's column indicating a phone connected to an Energous receiver was receiving 0mW of power is due to the phone not being connected to Energous' cloud-based reporting system, rather than due to the phone not being charged.
    • Energous is higher today, and trading near a 2016 high of $9.73 (set on Monday).
    • Last week: Energous jumps after column provides more fuel for Apple hopes
     
     
     
     
    | 1:39 PM | 110 Comments
  • SAGE

    Sell-siders push back on bearish SA article on SAGE Therapeutics; shares up 2%

    • Institutional firms rush to support SAGE Therapeutics (SAGE +2.3%) after it tumbled almost 13% yesterday after SA Contributor Kerrisdale Capital Management penned an article questioning the efficacy of the company's lead product candidate, SAGE-547, and the size of its potential market.
    • The stock's behavior would appear to support Kerrisdale's bearish view. Shares have lost almost 70% of their value since peaking at $89.04 on June 9 of last year.
    • Leerink, one of the underwriters of its upcoming $150M equity offering, admits that the ongoing placebo-controlled trial (top-line data expected in H2) in super-refractory status epilepticus (SRSE) presents some risk of failing (all clinical trials do) but says Kerrisdale's benchmarks are off-target. Specifically, the 74% "seizure control rate" cited in the Ferlisi meta-analysis paper is a bit sketchy due to selection bias and the inconsistency in data resulting from four changes in the format of the questionnaire used. It claims a valid comparison of the 74% efficacy "rate" with SAGE-547's 77% success rate can't be made since its definition is different than the efficacy endpoint the company used in its Phase 1/2 trial and is using it its Phase 3 study, namely the number of SRSE patients able to be weaned off all third-line agents and remain off for at least 24 hours. It also says the U.S. addressable market is ~25K cases, not 4K Kerrisdale mentions. Leerink has a point here. The premier health database the company used to arrive at its estimate showed ~6,300 SRSE patients who spent at least two days in the ICU out of a total of 6M hospitalizations, ~20% of the U.S. total. Assuming a comparable proportion for the entire U.S., not unreasonable for an estimate, shows a country-wide incidence of 31.5K SRSE cases, so 25K appears to be a reasonable guess. It maintains its Outperform rating and $58 (93% upside) price target, quite a bit lower that its original target of $107 which was lowered to $80 last November.
    • William Blair makes basically the same points as Leerink. It maintains an Outperform rating and $58 price target. When it initiated coverage a year ago, its target was $75.
    • Previously: Sage Therapeutics off 17% on SA article that questions effectiveness of lead product candidate (March 23)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:11 PM | 1 Comment
  • MOD

    Modine Manufacturing raised to Buy at Seaport Global

    • Modine Manufacturing (MOD +6.7%) is upgraded to Buy from Neutral with a $12 price target at Seaport Global Securities.
    • The firm says much of its optimism revolves around MOD's SDG program, which targets 7%-8% operating margins by the end of FY 2018 vs. 4%-5% in prior years (FY 2017 begins next week) and $100M of acquired revenue intended to diversify away from core vehicular markets, among other goals.
    • Seaport sees several paths for MOD to beat its new expectations, even if end markets deteriorate, and the valuation does not need to match the peer group for substantial upside in the share price.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM
  • CRDS

    Crossroads sells off in wake of deals to sell storage business, patents

    • After dropping slightly yesterday, Crossroads (CRDS -12.6%) is seeing bigger losses today following a Tuesday evening announcement the company is selling its product portfolio and maintenance business (including its StrongBox and SPHiNX storage lines) to Canada's StrongBox Data Solutions (SDSI) for $1.85M in cash.
    • Crossroads has also inked a deal with private AQUA Licensing to market and sell its non-'972 patent portfolio (contains 138 patents and pending patents). However, the company "can provide no assurance regarding the timing or value of a transaction, or even if one will occur."
    • 27 Crossroads employees have joined SDSI. CEO Richard Coleman declares the SDSI deal will significantly reduce Crossroads' cash burn, and allows it to focus on IP monetization. The company had $7.7M in cash at the end of its January quarter (down $3.9M Q/Q). It struck a deal last fall to obtain $10M in litigation financing for its '972 portfolio.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:47 PM | 1 Comment

  • Midday Gainers/ Losers

    • Gainers: GSI +41%. CDRB +25%. TIVO +21%. APRI +17%. MRCY +15%. SKY +14%. CDNA +12%. AXDX +12%. TGEN +11%. BTU +10%.
    • Losers: OTC:DSKX -35%. PTLA -27%. TNDM -19%. SPKE -18%. SIGM -17%. CHNR -17%. PTX -15%. HPJ -14%. LCI -13%. AM -13%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:47 PM | 2 Comments
  • EGO

    Eldorado Gold -4% after huge Q4 loss, dividend suspension

    • Eldorado Gold (EGO -3.9%) is sharply lower after posting a $1.24B Q4 loss, including $1.25 in writedowns, largely on its projects in Greece; after stripping out the writedowns, EGO had a $19.3M adjusted loss, or $0.02/share.
    • EGO says it is suspending its semi-annual dividend, citing low gold prices even though gold has rallied YTD; eliminating the dividend will save $14M/year.
    • Even after the dividend suspension, BMO Capital analyst Andrew Kaip expects EGO will draw funds from its $375M credit facility in order to fund its “longer-dated” growth initiatives.
    • While most of EGO's growth plans are in Greece, where there is still plenty of uncertainty, one of the questions around the company is what it will do with Chinese assets it would like to sell; CEO Paul Wright says he expects a resolution in the "near term” and to provide an update on the process in Q2.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:42 PM | 1 Comment
  • MXL

    MaxLinear slumps after Microsemi strikes deal to sell rival business

    • MaxLinear (MXL -4.8%) is selling off after Microsemi, historically a rival in the telecom infrastructure chip market, announced it's selling its RF/microwave, embedded security, and custom microelectronics businesses to embedded processing system maker Mercury Systems for $300M.
    • Mercury declared the deal "nearly doubles the size of our RF and Microwave business, adding new capabilities, scale and synergies." TheFly observes MaxLinear recently stated in a recent presentation (.pdf) its "Infrastructure & Other" business, for which Microsemi and several others are named rivals, only accounts for 8%-10% of its revenue (see page 13). However, the company also suggested the business has stronger growth prospects than its other segments, and is a priority area for investments.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:27 PM | 4 Comments
  • ACN

    Accenture makes new highs after FQ2 beat, FY16 guidance hike; dividend declared

    • Accenture's (ACN +3.8%) FQ2 beat has been accompanied by guidance for FY16 (ends Aug. '16) adjusted EPS of $5.21-$5.32, up from a prior $5.09-$5.24 and mostly above a $5.22 consensus.
    • FY16 constant currency revenue growth guidance has been hiked to 8%-10% from 6%-9%. With forex still expected to have a 5% impact, dollar-based revenue growth guidance is at 3%-5%, in-line with a 3.7% consensus.
    • FQ3 revenue guidance of $8.1B-$8.35B is in-line with an $8.17B consensus. FY16 op. cash flow and free cash flow guidance respectively remain at $4.1B-$4.4B and $3.6B-$3.9B.
    • Bookings: New bookings rose by $200M Y/Y to $9.5B. Consulting bookings rose by $800M to $5B, while outsourcing bookings (pressured to an extent by cloud services adoption) fell by $600M to $4.5B. Forex had a 6% impact on bookings growth.
    • Segment performance: Telecom/media/tech revenue +6% Y/Y to $1.6B. Financial services +6% to $1.7B. Health/public service +12% to $1.5B. Products (manufacturing) +8% to $2B. Resources (hurt by weak oil/commodity prices) -3% to $1.2B.

      Overall, consulting revenue rose 12% to $4.3B, while outsourcing was roughly flat at $3.7B. CEO Pierre Nanterme asserts Accenture "gained significant market share."
    • Regional performance: North America revenue +11% to $3.8B. Europe (9% forex impact) +5% to $2.8B. "Growth markets" (14% forex impact) -4% to $1.4B.
    • Financials: Buybacks once more boosted EPS: $829M was spent to repurchase 8.1M shares. $6.4B is left on Accenture's buyback authorization. Op. margin rose 10 bps Y/Y to 13.7%. Accenture ended FQ2 with $3B in cash and less than $30M in debt.
    • Along with the numbers, Accenture has declared its semi-annual $1.10/share dividend (2% yield). The next dividend will be paid on May 13 to shareholders on record as of April 15.
    • Accenture's FQ2 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM
  • PBR

    Petrobras cut to Sell at Deutsche Bank, as dividends unlikely in 2016-17

    • Petrobras (PBR -2.4%) is downgraded to Sell from Hold at Deutsche Bank, which says it sees no upside for the shares with negative net income likely in both 2016 and 2017, thus removing any hope for a dividend.
    • Deutsche Bank says PBR had indicated it could recycle pre-tax losses of $3.7B in 2016 and $4.4B in 2017 through its income statement, but this would “almost entirely offset our estimated 'clean' [profit before taxes] of $3.7B in 2017 and $4.8B in 2018,” which may mean delays in preferred dividends until 2018 and ordinary dividends until 2021.
    • However, the firm thinks PBR’s business is likely to be stable, "a big improvement on the going concern uncertainty a year ago, with the company’s ability to fund itself no longer in doubt."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:34 AM | 20 Comments
  • ET

    Energy Transfer slashes expectations for Williams deal

    • Energy Transfer Equity (ETE -4.9%) drastically cuts expectations for its takeover of Williams Cos. (WMB -7.2%), due in part to lower oil prices and the increased cost of capital.
    • ETE now says it expects the base case for EBITDA from commercial synergies from the deal to total ~$170M/year by 2020, compared with previous forecasts of more than $2B; EBITDA from commercial synergies could total ~$590M/year if oil prices recovery to the $53.97-$64.26/bbl range in 2020, but that still would be far below previous forecasts.
    • ETE also says it plans to grant awards under a long-term incentive plan that will dilute WMB stockholders' position in Energy Transfer Corp., the vehicle ETE is launching to buy WMB; the company also says it likely would need to significantly reduce its presence in WMB's home state of Oklahoma.
    • Also: ETP -1.3%, WPZ -4.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:16 AM | 171 Comments
  • CGNX

    Cognex falls sharply as CLSA downgrades on capex and iPhone-related concerns

    • Believing manufacturing capex remains weak and that the just-launched iPhone SE can be manufactured using older equipment, CLSA's Jeremie Carpon has downgraded industrial machine vision system maker Cognex (CGNX -6.7%) to Underperform from Outperform.
    • Carpon sees a high risk Cognex won't be able to hit consensus estimates. Shares currently go for 25x a 2017 EPS consensus of $1.47, and remain up 19% from where they traded before Cognex posted a Q4 beat on Feb. 10.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM
  • MACK

    Merrimack's ONIVYDE included in this year's treatment guidelines for pancreatic cancer; shares up 4%

    • Merrimack Pharmaceuticals (MACK +3.7%) announces that ONIVYDE (irinotecan liposome injection), in combination with the chemo agent fluorouracil (5-FU) and a folic acid derivative called leucovorin, has been included in the 2016 Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology for the treatment of pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
    • The guidelines recognize the ONIVYDE regimen as a category 1 second-line treatment for metastatic pancreatic cancer patients who have been previously treated with gemcitabine-based therapy. Category 1 status means the therapy is supported by the highest level of evidence and NCCN (National Comprehensive Cancer Network) consensus that the intervention is appropriate. The FDA cleared it for the indication in October 2015.
    • Pancreatic cancer is one of the most resistant to treatment. It strikes ~53K American each year. Only 7% survive five years or longer.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:59 AM | 4 Comments
  • WFC

    Wells Fargo started with a Sell rating at UBS

    • "We see risks to Wells Fargo's (WFC -2.4%) revenue growth and credit performance," says UBS. "Coupled with a valuation on the high end of peers and consensus estimates that have not come down much, [this] puts Wells Fargo shares at risk of under performance in our view."
    • The bank has a strong management team and franchise, acknowledges UBS, but this isn't news and is priced into the stock.
    • Though down sharply on the session, Wells isn't doing any worse than the rest of the major U.S. banks.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:50 AM | 23 Comments
  • MS

    Financials lead market lower

    • Oil's lower by 2.9% today and about 10% for the week, but it's the financial sector (XLF -1.3%) leading the S&P 500's 0.5% decline today. This even as Jim Bullard becomes the latest Fed speaker to more or less disavow last week's dovish FOMC meeting result, and suggest higher rates could come as soon as April's get-together.
    • Morgan Stanley (MS -2.9%), Citigroup (C -2.5%), BB&T (BBT -1.3%), U.S. Bancorp (USB -1.3%), MetLife (MET -2.8%), Prudential (PRU -3.5%)
    • ETFs: XLF, FAS, FAZ, KRE, UYG, VFH, KBE, IYF, BTO, IAT, IYG, SEF, FNCL, FXO, KBWB, QABA, RYF, FINU, KBWR, KRU, RWW, FINZ, KRS, XLFS
     
     
     
     
    | 10:43 AM | 14 Comments
  • DSKX

    DS Healthcare chief gets the hook for dubious financial dealings; shares down 27%

    • Thinly traded nano cap DS Healthcare Group (OTC:DSKX -27.1%) slumps on double normal volume, albeit on turnover of only 240K shares, in response to a regulatory filing that discloses some bad news.
    • In an 8-K filed after yesterday's close, the company reports that it fired CEO Daniel Khesin on March 17 for violating his fiduciary duty to the company and for violating federal law. In addition, its accounting firm has determined its financial statements for Q2 and Q3 2015 can no longer be relied upon due to revenue recognition issues and improper equity transactions. The company believes the adjustments to the quarterly financial statements will be material when finalized.
    • Through his attorney, Mr. Khesin has advised the company that he disagrees with the findings of the Audit Committee and believes his removal was improper and constitutes wrongful termination.
    • Bleecker Street Research reported on the company's problems in August.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:17 AM | 2 Comments
  • AM

    Antero Midstream units offered by Antero Resources priced at $22.40

    • Antero Midstream Partners (AM -12.8%) plunges at the open after Antero Resources (AR -1.8%) prices the sale of 8M of its units held in AM at $22.40/unit, for $179M in gross proceeds.
    • After the sale - and assuming no exercise of the underwriter's option to purchase 1.2M additional common units - AR will own ~62% of AM's outstanding common and subordinated units.
    • AM will receive no proceeds from the offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:07 AM
  • P

    Pandora spikes higher following dealReporter column, board addition

    • Much as the site wrote two years ago, dealReporter states Pandora (P +8.3%) is seen potentially attracting buyout interest. It speculates Amazon, Google, and Yahoo could make bids.
    • Separately, Pandora has added Tony Vinciquerra, a senior advisor to P-E firm TPG and before that the CEO of Fox Networks, to its board. The board now has ten members.
    • In February, the NYT reported Pandora is "working with Morgan Stanley to meet potential buyers," and has held discussions about selling itself. 35.4M shares (16% of the float) were shorted as of March 1.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:02 AM | 6 Comments
  • GOLD

    Barrick Gold to face U.S. class-action lawsuit over Pascua-Lama mine

    • Barrick Gold (ABX +1.6%) must face a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. related to its now-halted Pascua-Lama mining project on the border of Argentina and Chile, after a federal judge yesterday granted class certification for the lawsuit which claimed the company misstated facts related to project.
    • The judge rules that shareholders who purchased ABX shares from May 7, 2009 through Nov. 1, 2013 are a part of the class-action lawsuit; investors who bought shares during the period say ABX touted Pascua-Lama as a world-class project even as it became clear that the project would fall short of expectations.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:50 AM | 9 Comments
  • TIVO

    TiVo reportedly in advanced talks to sell to Rovi; TiVo soars

    • The NYT reports DVR hardware/software provider TiVo (TIVO +17.4%) is in "advanced negotiations" to sell to program guide/content protection IP provider Rovi (ROVI -2%). TiVo has blasted off on the report, while Rovi is down moderately.
    • TiVo shareholders would reportedly receive cash and stock, and "probably" own ~30% of the combined company.  Rovi activist Engaged Capital (won two board seats last year) is said to have pushed for a merger with TiVo.
    • In addition to its DVR-related offerings, TiVo provides cloud-based content discovery services and set-top/portal server software for emerging markets, thanks to its acquisitions of Digitalsmiths and Cubiware. Both TiVo and Rovi derive a large % of their sales from pay-TV providers.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:41 AM | 3 Comments
  • VTR

    Ventas stung by Goldman downgrade

    • Goldman Sachs downgrades Ventas (VTR -2.1%) to Neutral from Buy after a strong run since the market bottom six weeks ago pushed the stock price through the team's $60 price target.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:41 AM | 17 Comments
  • LKM

    NQ Mobile higher following deal to sell FL Mobile stake to chairman/COO

    • NQ Mobile chairman/COO Vincent Shi plans to buy a 22% stake in the company's FL Mobile gaming unit, and then "participate" in the planned sale of FL Mobile by NQ and other shareholders.
    • Shi is paying RMB880M ($135M) for the stake. However, the details are once more complicated. Half the consideration will be paid in the next 60 days, while the other half "will be received by the Company upon satisfaction of certain conditions contained in the Agreement and the FL Mobile Divestment."

  • PTLA

    Trading in Portola Pharma halted pending news; Phase 3 APEX study of extended-duration betrixaban fails to achieve primary endpoint in first cohort; shares off 24% premarket

    • Trading in Portola Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:PTLA) halted at 6:55 am ET this morning pending news.
    • Update: Top-line results from the Phase 3 APEX study evaluating the superiority of extended-duration anticoagulation with oral betrixaban compared to standard-of-care anticoagulation with injectable enoxaparin [Sanofi's (NASDAQ:SNY) Lovenox (enoxaparin sodium injection] for the prevention of blood clots [venous thromboembolism (VTE)] in acute medically ill patients failed to achieve its primary endpoint in the first cohort.
    • The 7,513-subject study was designed to assess the relative risk of the two therapies as measured by a composite endpoint of ultrasound-detected (asymptomatic) proximal deep venous thrombosis (DVT), symptomatic DVT, non-fatal pulmonary embolism (PE) or VTE-related death in high-risk acute medically ill patients treated with oral betrixaban for 35 - 47 days compared to standard-of-care- injectable enoxaparin for 6 - 14 days.
    • The study population consisted of three pre-specified patient groups: Cohort 1 - patients with elevated D-dimer levels (62% of the population); Cohort 2: patients with elevated D-dimer levels aged at least 75 years (91% of the population) and the overall study population. D-dimer is a test for inappropriate blood clots.
    • The trial incorporated an enrichment strategy and statistical analysis plan derived from FDA guidance. Per the protocol, the primary efficacy analysis was performed on Cohort 1. The p value had to be no higher that 0.05 in order to test Cohort 2 which, in turn, had to have a p value no higher than 0.05 in order to test the overall study population.
    • The p value in Cohort 1 was 0.054, slightly above the threshold to proceed to Cohort 2, which had a p value of 0.029. The overall population's p value was lower still, 0.006. The relative risk calculation favored betrixaban in all three cohorts, showing a 19 - 24% lower risk of events compared to enoxaparin.
    • The company believes the data in Cohort 1 were strong enough to support the full assessment in Cohort 2 and the overall study population. It also believes the data are robust enough to support a New Drug Application (NDA) later this year. As such, it intends to discuss the data with regulatory agencies.
    • According to the company, ~20M acute medically ill patients in the G7 countries are at risk of developing VTE while hospitalized or following discharge. More than 1M VTEs and 150K VTE-related deaths occur in this population each year despite the use of injectable enoxaparin.
    • Fast Track-tagged betrixaban is a once-daily orally administered Factor Xa inhibitor anticoagulant.
    • Management will host a conference call this morning at 8:30 am ET to discuss the study.
    • Shares are down 24% premarket on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:00 AM | 17 Comments
